in financial forecasting, statistics,

It's been a big interest of mine

in this field a long time ago. But
for now let's talk about the Global

linking in the upper right hand corner
of your screen
right now to my interview with Roger,
because that's where this unique
approach begins.
Roger established a very innovative project
many years ago, it's over 20 years old
now, I think quite a bit older than that.
But in any case,
what he has done is he used quantum
mechanical random event generators
spread around the world to capture
a continuous stream
of random events or random numbers, you
could even put it that way. Because they're
based on
quantum mechanics, one might say that
these generators - they're called eggs in his

think at the moment about a dozen of
them
operating simultaneously mostly in North
America and Europe
right now producing data every,
I think it's every 15 seconds.
That data is being recorded and you can

Consciousness
Project website, I'm posting the link
to that in the

that is underneath the video here, the
description of the video
will have a link you'll see.
The data
is available going back to around the
year 2000
from all of these eggs around the world
every 20 minutes. Well,
the idea came to Roger because
prior to setting up this project he had
been working at Princeton University at
the PEAR lab, the Princeton Engineering
Anomalies
Research Program which he describes in
the video,
looking at the possibility that people
can either
predict through precognition
or cause through psychokinesis,
perturbations
in these random event generators. The
suggestion
is that human consciousness is somehow
able to
interact at the quantum mechanical level
to cause these perturbations,
sometimes over great distances.
Roger thought to himself, "Well, you
could say that there's a kind of quantum
geometry, a quantum mechanical foam, a
quantum mechanical probability cloud
that underlies all of physical reality, and if
it's sensitive to human consciousness,
then it would seem to be the case
that disturbances in the physical reality -
earthquakes, big fires, huge political

that these perturbations in the group
consciousness
would be reflected at the level of the quantum
foam, and so that we would see unusual
deviations
occurring in the quantum mechanical
random event
generators, or eggs, in this system. And
indeed,
over the years they have correlated some
500 different events
with perturbations in the output
of the eggs in the system. I'm showing you a chart right now.
You can see the odds of something like this
occurring is 100 billion to 1.
Now, it's over a long period of time and
the effects are actually
very, very small, but when you can
show it happening consistently over 500
different
events, there's good reason for people to
hypothesize legitimately that these eggs
are somehow registering something
related to consciousness.
We're not exactly sure what or how and
there are many different
speculations about this data, and
arguments back and forth between
different groups of researchers, and between
researchers and their critics, but it's
strong data, nonetheless. But what I want to
share with you now
is a fascinating study just published
this year
in The Journal of Consciousness Studies
by a researcher named Ulf
Holmberg, an independent researcher working
in Stockholm, Sweden. He decided to do
something with the same data, but a
little different.
Rather than look at particular one-time
events to see if there's an unusual
correlation, or unusual
output of the random event generators in
the Global Consciousness Project,
he decided to mine that data and to create
what we call a time-series, because
that's exactly the way the data is
formatted, every 15
seconds going back 20 years.
I'm pretty sure it's 15 seconds, maybe it's
15 minutes.
But in the Holmberg study really what he
was looking at is daily.
For people working in the field of
financial forecasting,
a daily time-series of numbers is
crucial because if
you can find some variable
that correlates with the stock market, if
some variable
can predict for you what the stock
market is going to do tomorrow,
well you’ve got a gold mine. And that's what
he was looking for.
So he took the output
of the eggs over 20 years, more than
5,000 individual trials,
and he wanted to see if that output
would be
correlated with a global index of stock
market activity,
around the world. After all, the
eggs are scattered around the world.
At one time I think there were more than
one hundred of them operating simultaneously.
Today it's down
to about a dozen. But for his purposes it
didn't matter. What he did is he looked
at the most extreme standard deviation
reported amongst
all of the eggs throughout all of the
time periods during
the day, and he called that the maximum
deviation. He created his own time-
series of maximum deviations and then he
looked to see:
did it correlate with stock market activity,
over more than 5,000 days, in other words
20 years of data.
As a person, myself, who has worked in
the financial field
I can tell you that that's a huge data
set, because the markets go through so
many different conditions.
When I was working with neural networks
for financial forecasting we never
wanted to use
more than four or five years of data
because conditions just
don't remain the same. But in this case
what he found was yes, a significant
correlation predicting the following day's
movement in the global index of stock
market indices, and stronger correlations
with particular ones, like with the Swiss
stock market. Now,
statistically significant, yes.
The actual correlation accounted for
maybe one
or two percent of the change, but if you can
accurately predict one or two percent of
the change in the stock market
consistently over 20 years you can make
some money.
You've got to have a lot of risk
tolerance.
But it looks like from all reports
it's a legitimate finding, and it opens
up a huge
field of investigation for viewers who
may be interested in this sort
of thing. It requires a technical

Since I've worked with neural networks
myself in the past,
I'm very interested in this because
amongst other things if it proves
out it could be a way for the field
of parapsychology to support itself,
considering that it's probably among
the very most
under-funded fields of scientific study ever,
especially considering its importance.
But there's much more work that needs to
be done. For example,
Holmberg's particular statistic that
he called the maximum deviation for
every day looks good, it looks like it's
very promising but there are many other ways you could massage
that data and come up with other
statistics
from that data. Maybe the average
deviation is better than the maximum
deviation, for example.
It's unclear to me, it's not evidenced
in Holmberg's study in The Journal of
Consciousness Studies
as to whether he looked at other
statistics and discarded them,
or if this is the only one he looked at
and it turned out to show a positive correlation.
But working with neural networks I have
found that what's really interesting is
if you can get
one or two or three or four or a dozen
of these
very, very small correlations working
together,
because it's theoretically possible that
they can amplify each other or that,
working with many different tiny
correlations you can build a signal
which is much stronger because ultimately you really
would like to see 60 percent or
better
hit rates when you're dealing with
financial forecasting on a 50/50 basis,
that is,
"Will the market go up tomorrow or will
it go down?"
That's the basic question that you're
asking. So, my approach would be to
find various time-
series data that could be used as inputs
in a trading system, you
wouldn't base the entire trading system
just on that data.
There's been a lot of other work in
financial forecasting.

on using remote viewing for financial

It does seem to work well, at times
